Methimazole is a pro-drug of Carbimazole, and both are less favorable in early pregnancy due to potential risks to fetal development. Perchlorate is not commonly used in this context. analysis: In the management of hyperthyroidism during the first trimester of pregnancy, the primary concern is the safety of the developing fetus. Methimazole and its pro-drug Carbimazole are associated with teratogenic effects, particularly when used in the first trimester. Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred during this period because it has a better safety profile and is less likely to cause birth defects. Perchlorate is not typically used for this purpose. The consensus in medical practice supports the use of PTU as the safest option for treating hyperthyroidism in pregnant patients during the first trimester.
